1519459714_1PniNzyi8fygvwyBaLpA9oBDVWZ5f.body:
It seems to me that the ordinary ls on Linux already does that, without any extra parameters. A command 

    ls > /tmp/foo.txt

creates a file with a list where everything has been sorted. To limit the list, you may use the grep command with regular expressions:

    # An example that displays all lines that start with "1D". 
    # The "|" after the "ls" is a "pipe" that redirects the output of the "ls" to the input of the "grep"
    # The "-E" after the "grep" is a command line parameter that tells the grep to use regular expressions.
    # The "^1D" is a regular expression.
    # The "^" in the regular expression marks the start of the line. It's a general notion, not grep specific.
    
    ls | grep -E ^1D

The following command makes the grep match every line:

    ls | grep -E ^.

> [test20180221](#comment_1_13E6xCFLmbGYCNAPrKd3m5o6gTgnzMW4rd): ls | grep -E ^. " <--- what is it good for?

It's good for getting a different text layout at the screen, when not redirecting ls output to a file. The difference is visible, if You compare the console outputs of 

    ls
    # and
    ls | grep -E ^.
    # without redirecting any of them to a file.

> [test20180221](#comment_3_13E6xCFLmbGYCNAPrKd3m5o6gTgnzMW4rd): Try this one: ls -1 | egrep -f <(ls -1 | sed '0~2 s/.*/\$/')

Than You for the reply and thank You for the interesting example. 
I guess, different people do have different ways to process text :-D

> [test20180221](#comment_4_13E6xCFLmbGYCNAPrKd3m5o6gTgnzMW4rd): ls -lhtra | cat

If You place the following line 

    alias llls="ls -lhtra | cat "

to a text file witht the path of 

    ~/.bashrc

and start a new Bash session, then on a Bash shell You can type "llls", without the quotation marks, and hit enter to execute the same command.
